title: Georgi Dermendzhiev to replace Krasimir Balakov as Bulgaria manager
text:
Former Ludogorets and Levski Sofia boss Georgi Dermendzhiev is set to be appointed as the new head coach of Bulgaria, replacing the recently departed Krasimir Balakov.

The Bulgarian Football Union (BFU) confirmed the news on Monday, with Dermendzhiev taking over following widespread resignations due to sickening levels of racism directed at England players during a recent Euro 2020 qualification tie.

Dermendzhiev, 64, will replace Balakov, who resigned a few days after a 6-0 defeat by Gareth Southgate's side last Monday, with immediate effect.

Georgi Dermendzhiev is set to be appointed as the new head coach of Bulgaria this week

Sections of Bulgaria supporters had taunted the visitors with Nazi salutes and monkey chants, prompting match officials to halt the game twice.

The immediate aftermath of the match reflected poorly on Bulgaria, with Balakov refusing to accept that England players had been abused in Sofia.

Criticism came thick and fast, forcing Balakov into a complete back-track on his words, before issuing a half-hearted apology to the Three Lions.

Krasimir Balakov recently stepped down from his position after the racial abuse of England

The whole episode caused Bulgaria's national icon Hristo Stoichkov to break down in tears on national television while speaking about the disgusting racial abuse, which prompted instant action.

Along with Balakov's resignation, the entire Bulgarian committee announced they had tendered their resignations.

'Georgi Dermendzhiev is the new head coach of Bulgaria,' BFU vice-president Yordan Letchkov said on Monday, adding that Dermendzhiev would sign his contract in due course on Tuesday.

Hristo Stoichkov cried when talking about racism aimed at England players by Bulgaria fans

During a television appearance on TUDN, the legend got emotional when giving his thoughts

Dermendzhiev led Ludogorets to three consecutive Bulgarian league titles between 2015 and 2017.

His side became the first Bulgarian team to register a Champions League group stage victory when they beat Switzerland's Basel in 2014.

Winless Bulgaria are bottom of Group A in the Euro 2020 qualifying stage with three points from seven matches. They host the Czech Republic in their final group match next month.
